wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup 5/22/2015
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top employee engagement articles from around the industry to keep you informed and inspire positive impact in your organization.

Welcome to the New Era of Human Resources

The author argues that the HR department function hasn’t changed that much in the last century, however there are more technologies than ever available to help recruit, track, onboard, manage and report. The author argues that HR will have to quickly adapt or risk facing extinction since software has become more advanced, cost-effective, and reliable, especially since 2015 marks the first year that Millennials represent the majority of the American workforce. However, research shows adaptation has been slow: according to Deloitte, only 22% of respondents said that HR is adapting to the changing needs of their workforce.

10 Ways to Grow Leaders in Your Business

The author offers 10 tips on how to help develop leaders within your business. The top 5 include: Use big data, develop leaders early, educate and train employees, challenge employees, and let them interact with current leaders. Our favorite was #9: Inspire employees to be passionate. It sounds nice, but actually inspiring someone should be approached by certain steps. Facilitating creativity, encouraging side projects, utilizing surveys, and providing technology that enables them to participate in initiatives that matter most to them is a great place to start.

Millennials Have A Different Definition of Diversity and Inclusion

New research has shown a glaring difference between how different generations view and define diversity and inclusion at work. Most notably, Millennials see the two concepts very differently than Boomers, and Gen-Xers. Millennials view diversity as the blending of different backgrounds, experiences, and perspectives within a team, which is known as cognitive diversity. Millennials view cognitive diversity as a necessary element for innovation, and are 71% more likely to focus on teamwork.

How to Get Employees Excited About Their Work

To close the gap between leaders and employees, it is time for managers to change how they communicate with their teams. Rather than relying on traditional checklists for employees to tick off, leaders should strive to inspire their employees so that workers want to step up and own their results, going from I have to to I want to.

Beyond the Chief Sustainability Officer

Sustainability, corporate responsibility and the human costs of business are not only concerns of the Chief Sustainability Office, leaders throughout an entire organization have reason to care and drive change. From the CFO to the CMO, executives are starting to change things up and incorporate this thinking into their long-term plans.
